com.stormpath.sdk.application
Interface Application

All Superinterfaces:
Deletable, Resource, Saveable
public interface Application
extends Resource, Saveable, Deletable

An Application instance represents a Stormpath registered application.

Since:
0.1

getName

String getName()
Returns the Application's name. An application's name must be unique across all other applications in the owning Tenant.

Returns:
the Application's name

setName

void setName(String name)
Sets the application's name. Application names must be unique within a Tenant.

Parameters:
name - tenant-unique name of the application.

getStatus

ApplicationStatus getStatus()
Returns the application's status. Application users may login to an enabled application. They may not login to a disabled application.

Returns:

getAccounts

AccountList getAccounts()
Returns a paginated list of all accounts that may login to the application.

Tip: Instead of iterating over all accounts, it might be more convenient (and practical) to execute a search for one or more accounts using the getAccounts(com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountCriteria) or getAccounts(java.util.Map) methods instead of this one.

Returns:
a paginated list of all accounts that may login to the application.
See Also:
getAccounts(com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountCriteria), getAccounts(java.util.Map)

getAccounts

AccountList getAccounts(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
Returns a paginated list of the accounts that may login to the application that also match the specified query criteria.

Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

 .../applications/applicationId/accounts?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...

Parameters:
queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
Returns:
a paginated list of the application's accounts that match the specified query criteria.
Since:
0.8

getAccounts

AccountList getAccounts(AccountCriteria criteria)
Returns a paginated list of the accounts that may login to the application that also match the specified query criteria. The Accounts utility class is available to help construct the criteria DSL. For example: 
 application.getAccounts(Accounts
     .where(Accounts.surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(Accounts.givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
or, if using static imports: 
 import static com.stormpath.sdk.account.Accounts.*;

 ...

 application.getAccounts(where(
     surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));

Parameters:
criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
Returns:
a paginated list of the application's accounts that match the specified query criteria.
Since:
0.8

createAccount

Account createAccount(Account account)
                      throws ResourceException
Creates a new Account that may login to this application.

This is mostly a convenience method; it delegates creation to the Application's designated defaultAccountStore, and functions as follows:

  • If the defaultAccountStore is a Directory: the account is created in the Directory and returned.
  • If the defaultAccountStore is a Group: the account is created in the Group's Directory, assigned to the Group, and then returned.

Parameters:
account - the account to create/persist
Returns:
a new Account that may login to this application.
Throws:
ResourceException - if the Application does not have a designated defaultAccountStore or if the designated defaultAccountStore does not allow new accounts to be created.
Since:
0.9

createAccount

Account createAccount(CreateAccountRequest request)
                      throws ResourceException
Creates a new Account that may login to this application according to the request criteria.

This is mostly a convenience method; it delegates creation to the Application's designated defaultAccountStore, and functions as follows:

  • If the defaultAccountStore is a Directory: the account is created in the Directory and returned.
  • If the defaultAccountStore is a Group: the account is created in the Group's Directory, assigned to the Group, and then returned.

Example

 application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).build());

If you would like to force disabling the backing directory's account registration workflow: 

 application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).setRegistrationWorkflowEnabled(false).build());
If you would like to force the execution of the registration workflow, no matter what the backing directory configuration is: 
 application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).setRegistrationWorkflowEnabled(true).build());
If you would like to retrieve the account's custom data in the response of the account creation. 
 application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).withResponseOptions(Accounts.options().withCustomData()).build());

Parameters:
request - the account creation request
Returns:
a new Account that may login to this application.
Throws:
ResourceException - if the Application does not have a designated defaultAccountStore or if the designated defaultAccountStore does not allow new accounts to be created.
Since:
0.9

getGroups

GroupList getGroups()
Returns all Groups accessible to the application (based on the Application's associated Account stores).

Tip: Instead of iterating over all groups, it might be more convenient (and practical) to execute a search for one or more groups using the getGroups(java.util.Map) method instead of this one.

all Groups accessible to the application (based on the Application's associated Account stores).
Since:

See Also:

getGroups

GroupList getGroups(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
Returns a paginated list of the groups accessible to the application (based on the app's mapped Account stores) that also match the specified query criteria.

Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

 .../applications/applicationId/groups?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...

Parameters:
queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
Returns:
a paginated list of the application's groups that match the specified query criteria.
Since:
0.8

getGroups

GroupList getGroups(GroupCriteria criteria)
Returns a paginated list of the groups accessible to the application (based on the app's mapped Account stores) that also match the specified query criteria. The Groups utility class is available to help construct the criteria DSL. For example: 
 application.getGroups(Groups
     .where(Groups.description().containsIgnoreCase("foo"))
     .and(Groups.name().startsWithIgnoreCase("bar"))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
or, if using static imports: 
 import static com.stormpath.sdk.group.Groups.*;

 ...

 application.getGroups(where(
     description().containsIgnoreCase("foo"))
     .and(name().startsWithIgnoreCase("bar"))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));

Parameters:
criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
Returns:
a paginated list of the application's accessible groups that match the specified query criteria.
Since:
0.8

sendPasswordResetEmail

Account sendPasswordResetEmail(String accountUsernameOrEmail)
Sends a password reset email for the specified account username or email address. The email will contain a password reset link that the user can click or copy into their browser address bar.

This method merely sends the password reset email that contains the link and nothing else. You will need to handle the link requests and then reset the account's password as described in the verifyPasswordResetToken(String) JavaDoc.

Parameters:
accountUsernameOrEmail - a username or email address of an Account that may login to the application.
Returns:
the account corresponding to the specified username or email address.
See Also:
verifyPasswordResetToken(String)

verifyPasswordResetToken

Account verifyPasswordResetToken(String token)
Verifies a password reset token in a user-clicked link within an email.

Base Link Configuration

You need to define the Base link that will process HTTP requests when users click the link in the email as part of your Application's Workflow Configuration within the Stormpath UI Console. It must be a URL served by your application's web servers. For example: 
 https://www.myApplication.com/passwordReset

Runtime Link Processing

When an application user clicks on the link in the email at runtime, your web server needs to process the request and look for an spToken request parameter. You can then verify the spToken, and then finally change the Account's password.

Usage Example:

Browser: GET https://www.myApplication/passwordReset?spToken=someTokenValueHere

Your code: 

 String token = httpServletRequest.getParameter("sptoken");

 Account account = application.verifyPasswordResetToken(token);

 //token has been verified - now set the new password with what the end-user submits:
 account.setPassword(user_submitted_new_password);
 account.save();

Parameters:
token - the verification token, usually obtained as a request parameter by your application.
Returns:
the Account matching the specified token.
Since:
0.4

authenticateAccount

AuthenticationResult authenticateAccount(AuthenticationRequest request)
                                         throws ResourceException
Authenticates an account's submitted principals and credentials (e.g. username and password). The account must be in one of the Application's assigned account stores. If not in an assigned account store, the authentication attempt will fail.

Example

Consider the following username/password-based example: 

 AuthenticationRequest request = new UsernamePasswordRequest(email, submittedRawPlaintextPassword);
 Account authenticated = appToTest.authenticateAccount(request).getAccount();

Parameters:
request - the authentication request representing an account's principals and credentials (e.g. username/password) used to verify their identity.
Returns:
the result of the authentication. The authenticated account can be obtained from result.getAccount().
Throws:
ResourceException - if the authentication attempt fails.

getAccountStoreMappings

AccountStoreMappingList getAccountStoreMappings(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
Returns a paginated list of the application's mapped Account stores that also match the specified query criteria.

Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

 .../applications/applicationId/accountStoreMappings?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...

This is a type-unsafe alternative to the getAccountStoreMappings(accountStoreMappingCriteria) method, and might be useful when using dynamic languages like Groovy or JRuby. Users of compiled languages, or those that like IDE-completion, might favor the type-safe method instead.

Parameters:
queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
Returns:
a paginated list of the application's mapped account stores that match the specified query criteria.
Since:
0.9
See Also:
getAccountStoreMappings(AccountStoreMappingCriteria)

getAccountStoreMappings

AccountStoreMappingList getAccountStoreMappings(AccountStoreMappingCriteria criteria)

 application.getAccountStoreMappings(AccountStoreMappings.criteria()
     .withAccountStore()
     .orderByListIndex();
or, if using static imports: 
 import static com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountStoreMappings.*;

 ...

 application.getAccountStoreMappings(criteria()
     .withAccountStore()
     .orderByListIndex();

Parameters:
criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
Returns:
a paginated list of the application's mapped account stores that match the specified query criteria.
Since:
0.9

getDefaultAccountStore

AccountStore getDefaultAccountStore()
Returns the AccountStore (either a Group or a Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated.

Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Group or Directory when creating accounts; this method returns the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new account persistence.

Directory or Group?

As both Group and Directory are sub-interfaces of AccountStore, you can determine which of the two is returned by using the Visitor design pattern. For example: 

 AccountStore accountStore = application.getDefaultAccountStore();
 accountStore.accept(new AccountStoreVisitor() {

     public void visit(Directory directory) {
         //the accountStore is a Directory
     }

     public void visit(Group group) {
         //the accountStore is a Group;
     }
 };

Setting the 'New Account Store'

You may set the defaultAccountStore by acquiring one of the Application's accountStoreMappings and calling setDefaultAccountStore(true) or by calling setDefaultAccountStore(com.stormpath.sdk.directory.AccountStore)

Returns:
the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated.
Since:
0.9

setDefaultAccountStore

void setDefaultAccountStore(AccountStore accountStore)
Sets the AccountStore (either a Group or a Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application.

Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Group or Directory when creating accounts; this method sets the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new account persistence.

Parameters:
accountStore - the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application

getDefaultGroupStore

AccountStore getDefaultGroupStore()
Returns the AccountStore used to persist new groups created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated. Stormpath's current REST API requires this to be a Directory. However, this could be a Group in the future, so do not assume it is always a Directory if you want your code to be function correctly if/when this support is added. Avoid casting the returned value directly to a Directory: use the Visitor pattern as explained below.

Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Directory (or maybe a Group in the future) when creating groups; this method returns the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new group persistence.

Directory or Group?

As both Group and Directory are sub-interfaces of AccountStore, you can determine which of the two is returned by using the Visitor design pattern. For example: 

 AccountStore groupStore = application.getDefaultGroupStore();
 groupStore.accept(new AccountStoreVisitor() {

     public void visit(Directory directory) {
         //groupStore is a Directory
     }

     public void visit(Group group) {
         //groupStore is a Group;
     }
 };
Again, in practice, Stormpath's current REST API requires this to be a Directory. However, this could be a Group in the future, so do not assume it will always be a Directory if you want your code to be forward compatible; use the Visitor pattern and do not cast directly to a Directory.

Setting the 'New Group Store'

You set the newGroupStore by acquiring one of the Application's accountStoreMappings and calling setDefaultGroupStore(true) or by calling setDefaultGroupStore(com.stormpath.sdk.directory.AccountStore).

Returns:
the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new groups created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated.
Since:
0.9

setDefaultGroupStore

void setDefaultGroupStore(AccountStore accountStore)
Sets the AccountStore (a Directory) that will be used to persist new groups created by the Application. Stormpath's current REST API requires this to be a Directory. However, this could be a Group in the future, so do not assume it is always a Directory if you want your code to be function correctly if/when this support is added.

Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Group or Directory when creating groups; this method sets the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new group persistence.

Parameters:
accountStore - the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new groups created by the Application

createAccountStoreMapping

AccountStoreMapping createAccountStoreMapping(AccountStoreMapping mapping)
                                              throws ResourceException
Creates a new AccountStoreMapping for this Application, allowing the associated accountStore to be used as a source of accounts that may login to the Application.

Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

Authentication Process and AccountStoreMapping Order

During an authentication attempt, an Application consults its mapped account stores in iteration order, trying to find the first matching account to use for authentication. The lower the AccountStoreMapping index (closer to zero), the earlier that store is consulted during authentication. If no matching account is found in an account store, the application will move on to the next AccountStore (next highest index) in the list. This continues either a matching account is found, or until all account stores are exhausted. When a matching account is found, the process is short-circuited and the discovered account will be used immediately for authentication.

When calling this method, you control where the new AccountStoreMapping will reside in the Application's overall list by setting its (zero-based) listIndex property before calling this method.

listIndex values

  • negative: attempting to set a negative listIndex will cause an Error
  • zero: the account store mapping will be the first item in the list (and therefore consulted first during the authentication process).
  • positive: the account store mapping will be inserted at that index. Because list indices are zero-based, the account store will be in the list at position listIndex - 1.
Any listIndex value equal to or greater than the current list size will automatically append the AccountStoreMapping at the end of the list.

Example

Setting a new AccountStoreMapping's listIndex to 500 and then adding the mapping to an application with an existing 3-item list will automatically save the AccountStoreMapping at the end of the list and set its listIndex value to 3 (items at index 0, 1, 2 were the original items, the new fourth item will be at index 3). 
 AccountStore directoryOrGroup = getDirectoryOrGroupYouWantToUseForLogin();
 AccountStoreMapping mapping = client.instantiate(AccountStoreMapping.class);
 mapping.setAccountStore(directoryOrGroup);
 mapping.setListIndex(3); //this is zero-based, so index 3 == 4th item
 mapping = application.createAccountStoreMapping(mapping);
Then, when authenticating an account, this AccountStore (directory or group) will be consulted if no others before it in the list found a matching account.

New Account Storage

If createAccount(com.stormpath.sdk.account.Account)

Parameters:
mapping - the new AccountStoreMapping resource to add to the Application's AccountStoreMapping list.
Returns:
the newly created
Throws:
ResourceException
Since:
0.9

addAccountStore

AccountStoreMapping addAccountStore(AccountStore accountStore)
                                    throws ResourceException
Creates a new AccountStoreMapping for this Application and appends that AccountStoreMapping to the end of the Application's AccountStoreMapping list, allowing the associated accountStore to be used as a source of accounts that may login to the Application.

Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

Authentication Process and AccountStoreMapping Order

During an authentication attempt, an Application consults its mapped account stores in iteration order, trying to find the first matching account to use for authentication. The lower the AccountStoreMapping index (closer to zero), the earlier that store is consulted during authentication. If no matching account is found in an account store, the application will move on to the next AccountStore (next highest index) in the list. This continues either a matching account is found, or until all account stores are exhausted. When a matching account is found, the process is short-circuited and the discovered account will be used immediately for authentication.

When calling this method, you are setting the new AccountStoreMapping to the end of the Application's overall list.

NOTE: If you already know the account store where the account resides, you can specify it at the time the authentication request is created (for example, UsernamePasswordRequest.UsernamePasswordRequest(String, char[], com.stormpath.sdk.directory.AccountStore)). This way you will be avoiding the authentication attempt to cycle through the Application's account stores.

Example

 AccountStore directoryOrGroup = getDirectoryOrGroupYouWantToUseForLogin();
 AccountStoreMapping mapping = application.addAccountStore(directoryOrGroup);
Then, when authenticating an account, this AccountStore (directory or group) will be consulted if no others before it in the list found a matching account.

Parameters:
accountStore - the new AccountStore resource to add to the Application's AccountStoreMapping list.
Returns:
the newly created AccountStoreMapping instance.
Throws:
ResourceException
Since:
0.9
